about.name: FUTURE EDUCATIONAL TECHNOLOGIES LAB
about.desc: The Future Educational Technologies Lab is led by Chris Rogers, a professor of Mechanical Engineering at Tufts University. We are housed in Tufts' Center for Engineering Education and Outreach (CEEO). We explore and provide technologies for K-12 science, math, and engineering education to bring engineering into pre-college students and excite children about solving problems and learning science and math.

projects.title: Solution Diversity in Engineering
projects.subtitle: Development of extension application and educational tool to support advanced engineering learning and solution diversity with LEGO products

related.title: Robotics Playground
related.desc: Robotics Playground is an experimental library of placemat instructions for robotics activities. Developed by researchers at the Tufts University CEEO, this library is designed to maximize solution diversity and foster student-driven learning.

related.title: Placemat Instructions
related.authors: Sara Willner-Giwerc, Hyejin Im, Chris Rogers
related.desc: This project explores the design of a new type of instructions for teaching engineering practices through robotics. Designed intentionally with solution diversity in mind, placemat instructions help lower the barreires to entry to the teaching and learning of engineering through robotics while promoting student engagement in the engineering practices of: iteration, collaboration, and dealing with uncertainty.

related.title: Introducing Reinforcement Learning with SPIKE Prime
related.desc: As artificial intelligence (AI) plays a more prominent role in our everyday lives, it becomes increasingly important to introduce basic AI concepts to K-12 students. Reinforcement learning (RL), as one of the main paradiams in AI, is appilied in many gamified environment and is interesting to learn. In this project, we designed two robot-based and one web-based sessions to help middle and high school students learn basic RL concepts.

related.title: CORP: Collaborative Online Robotics Platform
related.authors: Olga Sans Copé, Ethan Danahy, Chris Rogers
related.desc: CORP combines the potential of the Google web-based platform with the educational robot technology of the LEGO Mindstorms EV3 Kit. Designed for students in primary and high school, CORP allows students from different locations to interact collaboratively through sharing a Google Slide document with a custom add-on developed to talk to the EV3 robot.

related.title: SPIKE Prime Goes to College
related.desc: What is the ceiling of SPIKE Prime?

publications.title: Willner-Giwerc S., Danahy E., Rogers C. (2021) Placemat Instructions for Open-Ended Robotics Challenges. Robotics in Education. RiE 2020. Advances in Intelligent Systems and Computing, vol 1316. Springer, Cham. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-030-67411-3_21

Willner-Giwerc, S., Wendell, K., Danahy, E., Rogers, C., & Stuopis, I. (2020). Solution Diversity in Engineering Computing Final Projects. In American Society of Engineering Education Annual Conference and Exposition.

projects.title: Learning Through Play
projects.subtitle: Making the introduction of technology in classrooms more playful to children and more accessible to teachers to help children equip with the skills to thrive in a technology-driven world

related.title: Low-Cost Smart Motor
related.desc:
This amazing piece of tech will revolutionize the way you program robots. Imagine a world where you can program a robot the way you train your dog, or your kid, maybe just your dog.

The way you program this robot is by teaching what action follows what reaction.. for example, you can teach your motor to go to 60 degrees when you push a button, and turn to 120 degrees when you hold it for more than 1 second. This works by training the motor. That is how you would code it!!! Done!

related.title: Tech and Play
related.desc: Partnered with LEGO Foundation, we focus on providing pedagogical expertise and technical assistance for new ways of thinking about and applying technology in the classroom over Robotics. We develop tools for learning communities.

related.title: Draw2Code
related.desc: Draw2Code is a paper-based tangible computational kit for young children to create an interactive 2D augmented reality animation. Children use Draw2Code to make their paper drawing alive as an animated virtual sprite and control it using hand gestures. Engaging with the kit, children can design, code, and play with their creations. It exposes children to basic programming concepts through playful and tangible interaction.

related.title: Collaboration with PTC on Creating Digital Twins
related.desc: We worked on generating curricular supports for students learning Onshape, creating digital twins of LEGO robots that could simulate the physical robot’s motion, and developing new interfaces for spatial computing (control and monitor of robots in augmented reality).

publications.title: Im, H., Rogers, C. (2021). Draw2Code: Low-Cost Tangible Programming for Creating AR Animations. In Proceedings of the 20th ACM Conference on Interaction Design and Children.

related.title: SNAPR: Snap, Narrate, Auto Post and Reflect
related.desc: SNAPR is a tool that lets students capture and populate their e-portfolios automatically. In making/engineering, there is an emphasis on the final product and the ‘in-between’ stages are often ignored. In a making activity, e-portfolios provide observable opportunities for students to reflect on intermediate steps in their making, while also providing observable evidence for facilitators to assess students’ learning.
